Content:
@jl777c what does the `services` key in getpeerinfo's response mean?
```
  {
    "nodeid": 54,
    "protocolversion": 2,
    "ipaddress": "145.239.150.174",
    "port": 7770,
    "lastping": 1565698386,
    "time_started_con": 1565693756,
    "time_last_request": 1565698410,
    "services": 1073741829,
    "missbehavescore": 0,
    "bestknownheight": 1485272,
    "in_sync": "synced"
  },
```

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it should be 70000005 (not sure how many 0s)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the 7 means nSPV support with both addressindex and spent index

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: pretty cool that a superlite wallet can talk to the mempool

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I don't remember Electrum having any features like that, when I used it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: nspv has a lot more capability than electrum. skipcount alone enables it to handle addresses with very large number of utxo, though no client takes advantage of that yet

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you can search mempool for whether a specific utxo was spent in it, or if a specific address has received funds

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: oh, it also has an html wallet (and api) built in and runs locally, sort of big features

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if you look at the superlite gui, you will see that txid are hyperlinked and it displays all vins/vouts, with the vin txid hyperlinked

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so while it isnt a full block explorer, you can track down all the relevant details of your tx

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and it does it in reasonable performance. though if there is only one nSPV fullnode, that will be a bottleneck as there is a rate limiter of 1 nspv message per second per peer, for each message type

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: as you add more nodes with latest FSM branch, then make sure they connect to the seed node so they automatically propagate to the superlites

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: or add more seed nodes if they are not cross connected with the main seed. though always good to have a handful of seed nodes

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @jl777c what is so exciting about this, is that a superlite client can do blockchain analysis and not have to trust a 3rd party explorer

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i tried to make the GUI as fast as possible, while still keeping the internals single threaded

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: just one aspect, but that excites me. We all trust explorers way too much

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: exactly

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is possible that your peer is not up to date, but the Peers page will show the status of each, so if a specific request doesnt complete or has missing data, just refresh the page

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it seems to be working the same in unix and osx, but havent heard if it works with windows yet
